In turn, we see that such climate extremes have a large influence on deadly air pollution events in the future. For example, our projections show that the number of days in 74 major cities of China with winter PM 2.5 concentrations great than 150 μg/m 3 and 250 μg/m 3 (equivalent to the heavily polluted and severe polluted levels, respectively, according to the Air Quality Index in China; ref. 24) increases by 1.8 d (11%) and 1.1 d (42%), respectively, and we find that atmospheric stagnation events account for more than 70% of these high-PM 2.5 days and dominate these increases (
SI Appendix, Fig. S5 ). The reduction of surface wind speed and boundary layer height during stagnation events is unfavorable for the transport and diffusion of air pollutants, thus enhancing pollution haze ( 7). Similarly, the number of days in 74 major cities with summer daily 1-h maximum ozone greater than 90 ppb (approximate to the polluted level) increases by 3.8 d (12%) (
SI Appendix, Fig. S5 ), and about 14% of these high-ozone days occur during heat wave days as high temperatures are favorable for photochemical formation of ozone ( 17).
